entry.title: Uploading Email Templates into Emarsys using API
entry.content:
Uploading Email Templates Using API

We are in a Situation to migrate the data from other applications to SAP Emarsys . As the data is important for us we need to get everything that keeps the system up and running. Unfortunately, SAP doesn't offer any out of the box solution to migrate the templates(like we do with contact and product data).

Here is the Solution that we have found.

We are uploading the email templates using Code and "campaign.create" api offered by Emarsys.

We need:
  • Two APIs (one for getting the admin Id and another for uploading the Templates).
  • Python or NodeJS environment. (To trigger the email templates and for some preprocessing if required).
  • Emarsys Account Owner role.

 

Configuration

Go to Management > Security Settings in your Emarsys Account.

  • Go to API Tab 
  • Create an API(For getting Admin Details).
  • Note down the client secret in a secure location(You can see the secret while creating the API).
  • Next add permission for "admin.list" and "admin.get". (this may take time to update the permissions).
  • Please configure the postman with your clientID and secret.
  • Get your Admin Details (AdminID). Please refer https://dev.emarsys.com/docs/core-api-reference/qzdmscigu4ezh-list-administrator-accounts if you need some help.
  • Create another API(For uploading the templates).
  • Note down the API details.
  • Add permissions for "campaign.create" and "campaign.get".
Data Preparation

Considering the data is exported from the source system as Filename with CampaignName and data inside it is the actual template.
Otherwise its your preference to prepare the data.

Final Step
import os
import requests

# Replace with your actual credentials
CLIENT_ID = 'your_client_id'
CLIENT_SECRET = 'your_client_secret'
TOKEN_URL = 'https://auth.emarsys.net/oauth2/token'
UPLOAD_URL = 'https://api.emarsys.net/api/v3/email/templates'

# Step 1: Get access token
def get_access_token():
    payload = {
        'grant_type': 'client_credentials',
        'client_id': CLIENT_ID,
        'client_secret': CLIENT_SECRET
    }
    response = requests.post(TOKEN_URL, data=payload)
    response.raise_for_status()
    return response.json()['access_token']

# Step 2: Upload HTML templates
def upload_templates(folder_path, access_token):
    headers = {
        'Authorization': f'Bearer {access_token}',
        'Content-Type': 'application/json'
    }

    for filename in os.listdir(folder_path):
        if filename.endswith('.html'):
            campaign_name = os.path.splitext(filename)[0]
            with open(os.path.join(folder_path, filename), 'r', encoding='utf-8') as file:
                html_content = file.read()

            payload = {
                "name": campaign_name,
                "subject": f"{campaign_name} Subject",
                "from_email": "your-email@example.com",
                "from_name": "Your Name",
                "html": html_content
            }

            response = requests.post(UPLOAD_URL, headers=headers, json=payload)
            if response.status_code == 201:
                print(f"Uploaded: {campaign_name}")
            else:
                print(f"Failed to upload {campaign_name}: {response.text}")

# Run the script
if __name__ == "__main__":
    folder_path = 'path/to/your/templates'
    token = get_access_token()
    upload_templates(folder_path, token)
``

That's it.
If you have any doubt you can reach out to me @HariVeerendra

entry.title: Next Generation Just-In-Time, Supply to Customer - Example in System
entry.content:
In previous blog (Next Generation Just-In-Time, Supply to Customer -... - SAP Community), we made a brief introduction to Next Generation JIT S2C solution. In this blog, I would like to show how system run by testing in SAP internal S/4HANA Cloud Public edition system.

We still take the sequenced JIT call business in automobile industry as an example. After we confirm all the related master data are prepared, we test in system by reference the main process described in previous overview blog:

  1. Create the customer JIT Call manually by Fiori App Manage Customer JIT Calls

You specify the External JIT Call Number (This can be from customer), Customer Vehicle Number, Customer Vehicle Model and other customer information. These cover all the request information from customer.

Component Groups will be automatically determined after you added new components.

In App Monitor Customer JIT Calls, you may check all the created JIT Calls with the status showed.

  1. Following most actions related to JIT Calls can all be executed in App Manage Customer JIT Calls By Component Groups.

Select your Teams Name, appropriate functions that could be performed by this team are displayed. Click the action button to perform corresponding actions.

The first action is Create Packing Group:

After the action being successfully executed, you may check the application log by clicking the Application Log on the same screen.

The application log detail will tell you what happened to this JIT call by this action.

Now the Packing Group is created based on the package specification defined, and you will find the new created packing group in the component group information of JIT Call:

The Internal Processing Status was changed from JIT Call Created(0100) to Packing Group Allocated (0130):

Since we will supply the customer JIT request with production. Now we release the JIT call to production:

Updated status also displayed on the same screen:

Packing Group Status updated too:

After the production completed, we perform the confirmation by clicking Confirm Production:

Goods movement posted while performing the production confirmation with movement type 261 for component consumption and movement type 131 for product receiving.

  1. The we perform packing related actions here: Release to Packing, Confirm Packing, Create Handling Unit from Package Group, Create Outbound Delivery.

After the outbound delivery created, We can see the delivery number on the JIT call Component screen:

We perform picking via App Pick Outbound Delivery:

Outbound Deliveries for Goods Issue:

Material document with movement type 601 generated after goods issue posting:

  1. Then we create billing document via App Create Billing Documents.

Now we will see the status of all actions on the customer JIT Call are completed:

We have some reports for the insights of Just-In-Time Processing. You may use Demand Analysis for Customer JIT Calls to compare the Customer JIT Calls and schedule line from forecast delivery schedules.

Use Analyze stock availability for Customer JIT Calls to compare JIT Call request quantities and available stock quantities.

entry.title: Re: Designing UI5 Apps as Business Solution for SAP Build Work Zone - Part 2
entry.content:
Hi  @theodore_abitbol 

this is now completely confusing to me:

  • Are you really sure, that when you start the app, in the network trace you first find a request for "ui5AppInfo.json" failing with 404 and then a 2nd request https://dev-tal-ks9oev3t.launchpad.cfapps.eu20.hana.ondemand.com/701acd48-8d90-47d3-9921-993e6601220b.cap-ui.argonuiappappcockpitruptureracine/~6924a2b3-72d7-4bcf-aab7-93938be7cd4f~/manifest.json?sap-language=EN failing as well?
    This would be impossible, because the first request is needed to know the URL for the 2nd one. So the 2nd one can't be send in that case.
  • So if removing the destination for the app-host removes the HTML5 app completely, means that the app-host is not enabled for the golden path flow. This is a bit strange, because I can see some content on it, which only exists in that case. 
    Anyway, please ensure that in the MTA the content deployer which deploys the app, you have defined the XSUAA instance as required similar to how it is defined in my sample here: mta.yaml#L14 
  • If the app is not listed under HTML5 applications anymore but you can still call it via managed approuter is also strange. Being listed there is a requirement that the URL works.

I think it is not possible to solve the problem from this chat here and also floods this discussion thread.
Are you able to create a support incident for this? This would allow to provide more internal info and share credentials. Please create an incident on CA-UI5-FL-CLS. Provide

  • your project content (at least the MTA)
  • a network trace (har file, no screenshots)
  • Login credentials to reproduce
  • Maybe also access to your space for my user matthias.schmalz@sap.com

Best regards
Matthias

  • Integrate BPA workflows directly into the SAP Fiori My Inbox of the S/4HANA system.
  • Trigger workflows from a custom application within S/4HANA, without using SAP Build Workzone.

Need to check the following possibility

  • Possible for integrating BPA workflows with SAP Fiori My Inbox in S/4HANA Private Cloud?

This integration will streamline workflow approvals within our existing Fiori Launchpad, reduce dependency on additional UI layers, and improve user adoption.

entry.title: Erfolgsfaktoren aus der ASCEND SAP S/4HANA Transformation bei Heidelberg Materials
entry.content:
Bei unserer monatlichen SAP Kaffee Ecke von SAP Training and Adoption erlebten wir diesmal einen besonders spannenden Praxisbericht zur SAP S/4HANA Transformation bei Heidelberg Materials. Christopher Gardner (Senior Change Consultant, Heidelberg Materials) und Hanna Mahnke (Change Management Consultant, SAP Digital Change & Adoption) gewährten uns wertvolle Einblicke in das ASCEND Programm bei Heidelberg Materials – mit besonderem Fokus auf den Menschen als zentralen Erfolgsfaktor im Change Management.

Eine kurze Umfrage zu Beginn verdeutlichte die Vielfalt unserer Teilnehmenden: 47% arbeiten im Change-Umfeld, 22% im Training-Bereich und 31% in anderen Bereichen wie Projektmanagement, Enterprise Architecture oder Vertrieb.

Praxisbericht aus dem ASCEND Programm - Ein Blick auf die SAP S/4HANA Migration

Heidelberg Materials ist mit rund 51.000 Mitarbeiterenden an über 3.000 Standorten auf fünf Kontinenten vertreten. Das Produktportfolio umfasst Zement, Zuschlagstoffe (Sand, Kies) und Beton.

Das ASCEND Programm führt weltweit über 30 Länder und globale Funktionen in Wellen auf SAP S/4HANA. Dabei sind mehr als 20.000 Nutzende betroffen. Eine besondere Herausforderung stellen die über 500 angebundenen Anwendungen dar sowie die lokale Verantwortung mit hoher Individualisierung der SAP Systeme in den Ländern. Parallel laufen weitere IT Projekte und Initiativen. Die ersten Länder sind bereits 2025 live gegangen, weitere Wellen folgen bis 2028.

Organizational Change Management (OCM): Struktur und Philosophie

Erstmals wurde ein dediziertes OCM-Team in die Projektorganisation eingebettet. Das Team wird von Katharina Fischer als Change Lead geführt. Hanna Mahnke und Christopher Gardner verantworten Kommunikation und Analytics, während Nancy Otanez und Thomas Stangl das Training verantworten. Auf Länderebene fungieren Country Transformation Leads (CTLs) als zentrale Ansprechpartner:innen, die wiederum mit den lokalen Key Usern interagieren.

Das ASCEND Programm verfolgt das Leitprinzip, dass es sich hierbei nicht nur um eine digitale, sondern vor allem um eine menschenzentrierte Transformation handelt. Systeme und Prozesse funktionieren erst dann optimal, wenn Menschen befähigt, informiert und aktiv integriert werden.

Erfolgsfaktoren für SAP S/4HANA Transformationen im Change Management

 

 

 

Change Leadership und frühzeitige Stakeholder-Beteiligung

Das Change Team bei HM investierte bereits sehr früh im Projekt viel Zeit in die Einbindung der lokalen Stakeholder. Die strukturierte Einbindung erfolgte von Global Process Owner:innen über Country Transformation Leads bis hin zu Key User:innen und Endanwender:innen – also über alle Hierarchieebenen hinweg. Ein gemeinsam erarbeiteter Workshop legte das Fundament für Change Vision, Mission und Werte als roter Faden durch alle Projektphasen. Der daraus resultierende interaktive Austausch bildete ein solides Fundament für die weitere, vertrauensvolle Zusammenarbeit.

Change Strategy & Plan / Change Leadership

Global-lokal verzahntes Vorgehen

Das Country Transformation Lead (CTL)-Netzwerk fungiert als wichtiges Bindeglied zwischen globaler Steuerung und lokaler Umsetzung. Zweimal monatlich finden CTL-Calls mit Status-Updates und Peer-Austausch statt. Globale Frameworks, die das Change Projektteam zur Verfügung stellt, werden lokal angepasst, während kontinuierliches Feedback das Change Framework schärft.

Change-Kommunikation

Ein durchdachter Kommunikationsplan dient als Bibliothek mit Kommunikationsschritten und -templates für jede Projektphase und Zielgruppe. Durch lokale Anpassung von Timing und Tonalität sowie Übersetzungen werden die lokalen Kapazitäten, Arbeitslast und Kultur berücksichtigt. Auch hier spielen die Country Transformation Leads eine zentrale Rolle, da sie vor Ort entscheiden, wann welche Aktivität umgesetzt wird und bilden damit eine wichtige Brücke von der globalen zur lokalen Organisation.

Change Analytics - Datengetriebenes Change Management am Puls der Zeit

Regelmäßige Pulse Checks bei Projektteam, Key User:innen und Endanwender:innen erfassen aktuelle Zuversicht, Trainingsnutzung und Zuversicht. Die Ergebnisse bieten wertvollen Einblick, inwieweit die bisherigen Change Maßnahmen greifen oder angepasst werden müssen. Dabei kann auch eine Wahrnehmung, wie es gäbe „zu viele Meetings", hinterfragt und durch Zusatzfragen validiert werden.

Training

Die Rollen- und Aufgabenverteilung sieht didaktisch-methodische Leitplanken vor, während die inhaltliche Ausarbeitung gemeinsam mit den Workstreams erfolgt. Das Projektteam erstellte ähnlich wie beim Projektplan ein Angebot, das vor Ort ausgestaltet werden kann. So wurden etwaige Widerstände vor Ort direkt gelöst oder entstanden erst gar nicht. Die Durchführung der Trainings liegt in der Verantwortung der Länder. Hierzu wurden die Key User:innen in einem Train-the-Trainer-Ansatz als Multiplikator:innen befähigt. Das Change Team stellte übergreifende Tools und Content in Englisch zur Verfügung, die Lokalisierung erfolgt in den Ländern. Eingesetzte Tools sind SAP Enable Now (inkl. Companion), Inhalte sind in Workday verfügbar.

Lernen, Verstehen, Anpassen

Die iterative Weiterentwicklung über den mehrjährigen Projektzeitraum umfasst Retrospektiven nach der ersten Welle mit konkreten Action Items. Dazu gehörten die Neuausrichtung des CTL-Netzwerks weg von Reporting hin zu Kollaboration, stärkere Lokalisierung des Key-User-Engagements sowie ein „Factory Approach" für wiederverwendbare Workpackages.

Diskussion und Q&A - Einblicke aus dem Austausch

Die anschließende Fragerunde brachte spannende Details zur praktischen Umsetzung in Kommunikation, Training, Standardisierung, Kultur und der Rolle datengetriebener Steuerung:

Kommunikationsstrategie in der praktischen Umsetzung - Wie funktioniert der Kommunikationsplan konkret?

Der Plan wird als Angebot verstanden und umfasst Stakeholderanalyse sowie die Unterscheidung zwischen strategischer und operativer Kommunikation. Pro Land werden Kernbotschaften als „Country Case for Change" erarbeitet. Das Muster führt von Awareness zu konkreten Informationen, Templates helfen bei Adaption und Timing. Global produzierte Videos lohnten sich aus Christopher's Erfahrung nicht – Länder setzen lieber auf eigene, kontextnahe Formate wie Statements lokaler Führungskräfte. People Manager Templates enthalten zusätzlich, was Führungskräfte wissen und leisten müssen; länderspezifische Ergänzungen erhöhen Relevanz und Nähe.

Motivation lokaler Veränderungsrollen - Wie lassen sich lokale Change-Akteur:innen motivieren?

Statt eines Change Champion-Modells wurden Country Transformation Leads (CTL) etabliert, die vom Land benannt werden (meistens IT-Verantwortliche). Landesspezifische Kick-offs mit CTLs und Vision/Mission-Arbeit fördern den Aufbau einer Beziehungsebene und damit Ownership. Das Netzwerk funktioniert vor allem über eine konstruktive Beziehungsebene auf Augenhöhe und begleitete Entwicklung für die kommenden Aufgaben. So können wir, beispielsweis bei einer ausbleibenden Rückmeldung einzelner CTLs persönlich den Kontakt suchen anstatt in der Hierarchie zu eskalieren.

Schulungsbedarfsanalyse und Umsetzung - Wie werden Schulungsbedarfe identifiziert und umgesetzt?

Die Bedarfsanalyse wurde in der Explore-Phase basierend auf den Fit-to-Standard-Workshops erstellt. Die nötigen Schulungs-Inhalte und Trainingsbedarfe werden gemeinsam mit den Stream Leads identifiziert. Im Train-the-Trainer-Ansatz werden die lokalen Key User:innen befähigt, die Inhalte lokal zu vermitteln. SAP Enable Now dient dabei als Autorentool, während die Entscheidung für Formate (digital, Blended, Präsenz) länderspezifisch getroffen wird. Im Grundsetup des Projekts waren 2-3 Ressourcen eingeplant, die offshore Content erstellt haben.

Rollenverständnis und Abgrenzung - Wie werden die Rollen CTL und Key User:in abgegrenzt?

CTLs fungieren als landesseitige Projekt- und Change-Schnittstelle, während Key User:innen neben Test- und Trainingsaufgaben das lokale Change-Engagement in die Organisation tragen.

Standardisierung vs. lokale Gewohnheiten - Wie wird mit dem Spannungsfeld zwischen Standardisierung und lokalen Gewohnheiten umgegangen?

Global Process Owner:innen arbeiten zusammen mit lokalen Pendants zur Analyse der Ausgangslage pro Land. Die Fit-to-Standard Workshops finden in den Ländern statt, inklusive Beteiligung aller relevanten Rollen. Das Ziel der Standardisierung wird als notwendig angesehen, ist lokal jedoch mitunter schmerzhaft. Beteiligung und gemeinsame Zielbilder erleichtern die Akzeptanz und ermöglichen langfristig einfachere, schnellere und konsistentere Änderungen.

Präsenz vor Ort und Budgetfragen - Wie lassen sich Investitionen in Vor-Ort-Präsenz rechtfertigen?

Aufgrund von Unsicherheiten in den Ländern und früheren Projekterfahrungen wurde gezielt in Vor-Ort-Präsenz investiert – fachlich und emotional unterstützend, insbesondere vor Go-Live. Die Führung unterstützte die Bedeutung; in Einzelfällen wurden Reisekosten zentral übernommen für Tests und um damit Sicherheit zu schaffen.

Interkulturelle Unterschiede meistern - Wie werden interkulturelle Herausforderungen bewältigt?

Das Headquarter wird erfahrungsgemäß als Hierarchie wahrgenommen – das multinationale Projektteam federte schon einiges ab, zudem half auch die lokale Entscheidungshoheit erheblich. Viele kulturelle Themen werden über die regionalen Strukturen gelöst, weitere Herausforderungen über die persönliche Beziehungsebene. Christopher betonte, dass bekannte Gesichter und lokale Stimmen wesentlich mehr Wirkung entfalten als zentrale Botschaften aus der Hauptverwaltung

Mensch im Mittelpunkt – wie bekommt man die relevante Aufmerksamkeit für den People-First-Ansatz?

Der Ansatz ist bei Heidelberg Materials nicht neu, erfährt aber seit einigen Jahren wachsende Aufmerksamkeit mit mehr Ressourcen. Aus Hanna's Erfahrung in anderen Projekten bleibt es jedoch grundsätzlich problematisch, dass Change Management noch zu oft zu spät hinzugezogen wird, was Ad-hoc-Maßnahmen nötig macht. Ein früher Start und echte Beteiligung (mehr als reine Information) sind erfolgskritisch. Die Menschen sollten als Konstante vom Start über Go-Live bis Hypercare im Mittelpunkt stehen.

Datengetriebene Steuerung in der Praxis - Wie funktioniert datengetriebenes Change Management konkret?

Pulse Checks liefern konkrete Zahlen zu Information, Trainingsnutzung und Zuversicht und ermöglichen gezieltes Gegensteuern durch gezielte Maßnahmen basierend auf Fakten. Die Wirkung einzelner Maßnahmen wird nachverfolgt, Ergebnisse stärken Argumentationen gegenüber dem Management und verbessern die Entscheidungsfindung bei der Priorisierung von Maßnahmen.

Fazit: SAP S/4HANA Transformation erfolgreich gestalten

Die ASCEND Transformation bei Heidelberg Materials zeigt eindrucksvoll: Konsequente Beteiligung, lokale Autonomie innerhalb globaler Leitplanken, klare Trainingsrollen, datengetriebene Steuerung und Vor-Ort-Präsenz machen den entscheidenden Unterschied.

Der Fokus auf Menschen – als Konstante vom Projektstart über Go-Live bis Hypercare – erweist sich als stärkster Hebel für erfolgreiche SAP S/4HANA Transformationen im großen Maßstab.

Ausblick: Nächste SAP Kaffee Ecke

Die nächste Kaffee Ecke im November widmet sich dem Aufbau von Key-User-Communities – einem Kernelement vieler S/4HANA-Programme, auf das wir uns bereits sehr freuen. Hier geht es zur Anmeldung

entry.title: Re: 🟠 Agentic Coding with CAP
entry.content:
Hi Aditi,
Our CAP MCP server is only meant for development, not for building AI agent applications with CAP. Many of the 3rd party libraries, like LangChain, also come in a JavaScript version. Though, I would recommend not to use most of these libraries and do it manually.

> or is it primarily designed to expose CAP application as MCP

Oh, it's not designed like this at all, it's only for development, with the side effect that you can talk to your CAP app during development.

> What are the benefits of using this as compared to using say, Microsoft CoPilot, SAP Joule, Amazon Q for Developers, etc?

It's an MCP server, and as long as these tools support MCP, you can use it with them. It will make sure they have the required CAP knowledge to solve the tasks.

entry.title: Overview of Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
Posting Rules can be used for processing bank statement items. A posting rule determines exactly how a bank statement item is posted. It determines which accounts are posted to on debit and credit sides, and also whether or not the respective debit or credit side is cleared. Amongst other things, a posting rule can consist of a posting area, a debit/credit account symbol, a posting type and an on-account posting key.

They tell the system which G/L accounts to debit and credit, depending on the transaction type.

For example:
When a customer payment is received → Debit the Bank Account, Credit the Customer Account.
When bank charges are posted → Debit Bank Charges Expense, Credit Bank Account.

hese rules ensure that every business transaction results in correct and consistent accounting entries without manual intervention.

Where Posting Rules Are Used

Posting rules are mainly used in:

  • Bank Account Management / Cash Management(Apps like Manage Bank Statement Rules, Manage Automatic Payments, Manage Posting Rules, etc.)
  • Payment Processing
    (e.g., in scope items like J58 – Bank Account Management )
  • Incoming and Outgoing Bank Statement Processing
    (via Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items apps)

How Posting Rules Work

Each posting rule defines:

  • Posting Area (e.g., subledger, G/L)
  • Debit/Credit Indicators
  • G/L Accounts to be used
  • Posting Keys
  • Document Type

For example:
When you process an incoming bank statement, a posting rule determines:

  • Which account should be debited (e.g., Bank Clearing Account)
  • Which account should be credited (e.g., Customer Receivables)

To understand what exactly a particular posting rule does (which accounts are posted and cleared), have a look at the table under Overview of the Posting Rules.

Viewing or Modifying Posting Rules

In the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, configuration is managed via SAP-delivered content.
Therefore Posting rules are usually predefined by SAP and cannot be modified.

Examples of relevant SSCUIs (depending on your scope items and country version):

  • 102386 – Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
  • 102387 – Assign Accounts to Posting Rules

How to View or Configure Posting Rules in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Unlike the on-premise system, where you use transaction codes (like OT83, OT74, etc.),
in the Public Cloud version, posting rules are managed via configuration activities (SSCUI) in the Manage Your Solution or CBC (Central Business Configuration) tool.

Step-by-Step: Viewing Posting Rules

Step 1: Access Configuration

  1. Go to the SAP Fiori Launchpad.
  2. Open the app Manage Your Solution (or Configure Your Solution in new systems).
  3. Choose Configure Your Solution tile.

Step 2: Find the SSCUI for Posting Rules

  1. In the search bar, enter:
    "Bank Statement" or "Posting Rules"
  2. Look for the following configuration activities (SSCUI IDs may vary slightly by country):
    102386 – Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements
    102387 – Assign Accounts to Posting Rules
    102385 – Define Posting Keys and Posting Types

Step 3: Open the Configuration Step

  1. Click Open Activity.
  2. In Define Posting Rules for Bank Statements (102386), you can view all pre-delivered posting rules.
  3. Each posting rule shows posting area, posting type, debit/credit indicator, and document type.
  4. These rules are SAP-delivered and cannot be changed directly in Public Cloud to maintain integrity.

Step 4: Assign G/L Accounts

  1. Open Assign Accounts to Posting Rules (102387).
  2. Here you can see which G/L accounts are assigned to each posting rule and account symbol.
  3. You may adapt account assignments if your scope item allows (depending on business role and configuration permission).

Step 5: Test the Posting Rule

  1. Go to the app Manage Bank Statement Monitor or Reprocess Bank Statement Items.
  2. Upload or simulate a bank statement.
  3. The system automatically applies the posting rule based on the external transaction code or mapping configuration.
  4. You can then check the accounting document to verify which accounts were posted (via Display Journal Entries).

Modifying Posting Rules (Limitations in Public Cloud)

In Public Cloud, you cannot create or freely modify posting rules as in On-Premise or Private Cloud due to SAP’s standardization policy.

You can:

  • View and extend posting rules using SSCUI.
  • Assign or change G/L accounts linked to existing posting rules.
  • Create additional bank statement rules (via Manage Bank Statement Rules app) that determine which posting rule applies under certain conditions.

You cannot:

  • Add new posting areas.
  • Define entirely new posting rules or posting types beyond what SAP delivers.

Relevant Scope Items (Pre-Delivered Configurations)

Scope Item Description
J58Bank Account Management
J77Automatic Payments
J78Cash Operations
BD9

Bank Statement Processing

These scope items collectively handle posting rule configuration and bank integration.

entry.title: Re: Internal activities & service activity elements.
entry.content:
Hi Harsh,

This behavior is actually quite common when working with internal activities and service activity elements in SAP Project Systems. By design, cost planning doesn’t automatically roll up from service activity elements to their parent internal activity. Each service element maintains its own cost data, and unless specific cost roll-up or cost distribution settings are in place, the internal activity won’t reflect those planned costs.

To achieve what you’re trying to do, you’ll need to make sure that the cost planning integration and aggregation settings are correctly configured. Start by checking your activity type assignment and cost element planning profiles. The internal activity should be linked to the same controlling area and cost element categories as the service elements to allow aggregation.

If you’re using standard cost planning transactions like CJ40/CJ42, try performing the cost plan at the WBS level and then executing a cost roll-up (CJ88 or CJ9E). This forces the system to consolidate the service element costs under the internal activity, which then enables period-wise distribution.

In some cases, organizations also handle this by defining a custom settlement rule or allocation cycle to move planned costs from service activities to internal ones. It depends on whether your controlling setup allows for that flexibility.

I’ve seen a few SAP professionals deal with similar cost flow issues during internal activity mapping. Having reliable study and reference material, like the structured resources available through Pass4future, can make understanding these configuration relationships much easier before applying them in your system.

Hope this gives you a clearer path forward.

entry.title: Re: Marketplace App UX Design Guidelines for SAP Users
entry.content:
If you’re designing a marketplace app intended for SAP users, the key is aligning your UX with SAP’s Fiori Design Guidelines and general enterprise usability principles. SAP users are accustomed to consistency, clarity, and efficiency, so your marketplace should feel familiar while still being intuitive.

Here are some guidelines:

  1. Follow SAP Fiori principles – focus on role-based, responsive, simple, and coherent design. Use familiar UI elements (tiles, cards, lists) that match Fiori’s visual language.
  2. Integrate smoothly with SAP workflows – minimize context switching by ensuring data flows between your marketplace and SAP systems (e.g., S/4HANA or Ariba) with minimal user input.
  3. Keep navigation clear – users should easily find suppliers, products, and orders. Use a simple top-level navigation or search-centric layout.
  4. Prioritize accessibility and performance – enterprise users often multitask; responsive layouts and quick load times matter.
  5. Personalization and analytics – show relevant items, purchase history, and quick actions based on user roles or past behavior.

SAP’s official Fiori Design Guidelines (experience.sap.com/fiori-design) are the best reference for UI patterns, layout grids, and interaction standards.

entry.title: Re: Goods receipt processing delay in SAP
entry.content:
When MII sends a GR confirmation to SAP, IDocs like MBGMCR or MBGMCR03 is processed immediately. The material document is created successfully. However, the update to the production order (AFKO/AFPO) — specifically the “Delivered Quantity” field — may not occur instantly. This update is typically handled by background jobs or update tasks that post-delivery quantities to the production order. Function modules like CO_ZV_ORDER_POST or whichever you are using are triggered post-GR. Update modules queued via V1/V2 update processes, which may be delayed due to system load or scheduling.

Go to SM13 to check if any update tasks are queued or delayed for the user or process.

entry.title: Re: SAML SSO configuration in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)
entry.content:
Hi @JefB 

The attribute used for SAML authentication depends entirely on the user's configuration and the values passed from their Identity Provider (IdP).

If the user base contains mixed identifiers—such as multiple domain names or inconsistent email formats—it is recommended to configure either a Custom SAML Mapping or use the User ID as the identifier. As long as the mapped values between SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and the IdP are consistent, authentication should function without any issues.

Regarding Joule/AI, there is no definitive SAP documentation explicitly stating that the NameID must be an email address. For reference, the official Joule integration guide can be found here:
Integrating Joule with SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Re: Error message when using Import Sales Orders
entry.content:
Even if your data appears correct and the format is set to [TEXT], the “Invalid Format” error during import (as described in SAP Note 2977875) can still occur due to hidden formatting issues, invisible characters, or mismatches between expected and actual field structures.

Even when everything looks fine, SAP’s import validation is strict. Here are the most frequent culprits:

Excel or CSV files may contain non-printable characters, extra spaces, or UTF-8 BOM markers. These can cause SAP to reject fields even if they appear correct. The solution is to open the file in a plain text editor (like Notepad++) and enable “Show All Characters” to inspect hidden symbols.

SAP expects specific field lengths and data types like numeric, date or text. If a field exceeds the allowed length or contains unexpected characters (e.g., letters in a numeric field), it triggers the error. The solution is to cross-check your file against the template or metadata provided by SAP for that import scenario.

Even if duplicates are not obvious, SAP may detect them based on internal keys (e.g., material number + plant). The solution is to sort and de-duplicate your file based on key fields.

Some systems interpret .csv or .txt differently depending on separators (comma vs tab). The solution is to try saving the file explicitly as UTF-8 encoded CSV with correct delimiters.

So in order to overcome from all the above "Invalid format" error is, validate with SAP’s Import Template and download the official template for your import scenario and paste your data into it. Use SAP Fiori App “Import Monitor”. It may show more granular error messages. Test with Minimal Data and try uploading just one or two rows to isolate the issue.

Check SAP Help Portal on Import Sales Quotations explains how invalid entries are flagged.

entry.title: Managing Change When Adopting AI
entry.content:
Adopting AI

The benefits of AI in supply chain management are evident, but implementing it might not be as clear.
Change management is an important aspect of any implementation which needs to be taken into consideration and made a priority ahead of any roll-out. Change management needs to be a high priority to ensure adoption. 
 
Conversational Planning

 In this blog, I'll explore the following topics

  • Change Management
  • How to practically adopt AI in SCM?

Change Management

Change management always starts with clear communication about the value of the upcoming change and crafting a plan that involves user input. AI in the supply chain will improve human experiences by automating repetitive tasks, enabling employees to learn new skills that will benefit both the business and their personal growth. With the conversational planning use case in SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management, a user can now reduce their planning time by at least 50% with the help of AI. This use case compliments the user's domain knowledge with AI driven data and real-time information. e.g. Plan all products that need to be transported to Orlando on a semi-truck with a 53' trailer. A user will interact through natural language. 

How to practically adopt AI in SCM?

Once a use case is setup in the test environment, users need to be trained on the new process to ensure better success. This is a link to the initial setup. SAP note 3573759 has more information of setting up conversational planning in SAP TM. The testing phase needs to be thorough with real-life data. These kinds of changes will probably require a pilot phase and can be rolled out once the value has been proven, these employees are likely to become your AI ambassadors fuelling excitement into the new technology which is always the best motivation for change ! Once the business is excited for these new improvements, these processes can be embedded in to the business. 
 
Route Planning with AI
 

This blog was an overview of what can be expected when implementing AI use cases in supply chain management and how to deal with change management.

In my next blog I plan to cover the another AI use case in SAP Transportation Management, AI assisted good receipt analysis. 

For more updates on Transportation Management please visit  https://community.sap.com/topics/transportation-management

A link to the configuration guide  https://me.sap.com/notes/3573759

If you have any questions on Transportation Management please visit https://answers.sap.com/tags/01200615320800000686

Feel free to connect with me on LinkedIn http://www.linkedin.com/in/ravine-lala-logistics .

entry.title: Firm Zone and Trade Off Zone dates in Schedule line-SA Output
entry.content:
- The business requires Firm Zone and Trade Off Zone dates of schedule lines in the SA print output.
- Firm Zone/Trade Off Zone dates need to be calculated based on the Firm Zone/Trade Off Zone Indicator from schedule lines and item SA data.
- Queries raised include:
1. How are Firm Zone and Trade Off Zone dates calculated?
2. Which CDS view provides Firm Zone/Trade Off Zone Indicator of schedule lines, or alternative methods to determine these dates?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Firm Zone and Trade Off Zone dates in Schedule line-S...
entry.content:
Hi,

The Firm Zone and Trade-Off Zone dates are not directly stored as date fields in the system.
They are derived values, calculated based on the number of days defined in the scheduling agreement item.
Currently, the Firm Zone/Trade-Off Zone indicators used for determining these dates are not exposed in any released CDS view for direct reporting or printing.
Hence, the standard Scheduling Agreement output form does not include these fields by default.

Firm Zone / Trade-Off Zone Calculation

  • The Firm Zone and Trade-Off Zone are calculated using the number of days maintained in the scheduling agreement item:

    • End Date of Firm Zone = Current Date + Number of Days in Firm Zone

    • End Date of Trade-Off Zone = Firm Zone End Date + Number of Days in Trade-Off Zone

The released CDS view for purchasing scheduling agreement schedule lines - see KBA 3561564.

  • This view currently does not include the Firm Zone or Trade-Off Zone indicator fields.

  • To determine these zones, custom logic must be implemented using the item-level configuration data.

Adding Fields to Output Form

  • To include Firm Zone/Trade-Off Zone dates or subcontracting component details in the output form, use extensibility options as per KBA 3008187.

  • You can extend the data source or form template to include custom-calculated fields or additional details (e.g., component materials for subcontracting scheduling agreements).

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: How to Migrate from SAP BTP Neo to Cloud Foundry – A Step-by-Step Technical Guide
entry.content:
1. Why Move from Neo to Cloud Foundry?

Migrating to the Cloud Foundry environment ensures that your cloud landscape stays aligned with SAP’s strategic direction. CF brings:

  • Multi‑Cloud Flexibility: Run workloads on AWS, Azure, or GCP.
  • Modern DevOps Experience: Container‑based runtime, CI/CD support, and open‑source tooling.
  • New Services: Access to SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Build Process Automation, SAP Integration Suite, and SAP Business Application Studio.
  • Future Compatibility: Long‑term SAP support and feature expansion.

2. Migration Roadmap Overview

Migration can be viewed in five phases:

Phase

Key Activities

Evaluate

Identify all active Neo services, subaccounts, and connected systems.

Plan

Define the migration strategy, sequence, and tool usage.

Prepare

Create CF subaccounts, assign entitlements, and set up connectivity.

Migrate

Execute migration using SAP Migration Packs and manual steps.

Test & Go‑Live

Validate integrations, perform cut‑over, and decommission Neo.

 

3. Service Mapping from Neo to Cloud Foundry

Neo Service

Cloud Foundry Equivalent

Connectivity Service

Connectivity Service (CF)

Cloud Integration (CPI)

SAP Integration Suite 

API Management

SAP Integration Suite – API Management 

Portal Service

SAP Build Work Zone 

Workflow Service

SAP Build Process Automation 

HTML5 Applications

HTML5 Apps Repository + Managed App Router

Web IDE

SAP Business Application Studio 

Document Service

SAP Document Management Service 

Git Service

Corporate GitHub / GitLab repository

 

4. Migration Preparation Steps

Step 1 – Create Subaccounts & Spaces

  • Log in to SAP BTP Cockpit → Create new subaccount.
  • Enable Cloud Foundry runtime and create spaces for Dev/Test/Prod.
  • Assign roles and quotas.

📘 SAP Help: Create Subaccount

Step 2 – Activate Entitlements and Subscriptions

Assign service plans and subscribe to Integration Suite, Work Zone, and BAS.

📘 Activate Subscriptions

Step 3 – Configure SAP Cloud Connector

Add the new CF subaccount to SCC and import on‑prem system mappings from Neo.

📘 Principal Propagation Guide

5. Migration Execution

A – SAP Integration Suite (Cloud Integration)

  • Use Migration Pack → SAP Note 2937549.
  • Export IFlows, Value Mappings, Certificates.
  • Re‑create security artefacts manually.

B – API Management

  • Run Tenant Cloning Tool (SDK).
  • Verify design‑time and runtime artefacts.
  • Update API provider hosts post‑migration.

📘 API Management Migration Guide

C – Portal and HTML5 Applications

  • Migrate Fiori Launchpad sites using the built‑in tool.
  • Replace neo-app.json with xs-app.json.
  • Deploy through HTML5 Apps Repository.

📘 Migrate HTML5 Apps

D – Workflow and Business Rules

  • Move Workflow to SAP Build Process Automation.
  • Export definitions and reimport to CF.

📘 Workflow Migration Blog

6. Architecture Overview – Neo vs CF Landscape

7. Post‑Migration Checklist

  • Validate destinations and trust configurations.
  • Re‑establish TMS routes for Dev→Test→Prod.
  • Conduct end‑to‑end testing.
  • Decommission Neo after stabilisation.

📘 SAP Cloud Transport Management Overview

8. Best Practices and Tips

  • Use side‑by‑side migration to minimize downtime.
  • Regularly review SAP Notes .
  • Begin with non‑production tenants.
  • Automate object transport via TMS where possible.
  • Maintain a rollback plan and track manual steps.

9. Conclusion

Migrating from Neo to Cloud Foundry is a strategic imperative to leverage SAP’s next‑generation cloud capabilities.
By following this roadmap and leveraging SAP’s Migration Packs and official guides, you can achieve a smooth, secure, and future‑proof transition.

entry.title: How to access 'Posting parameters' tab in 'Manage Contract' app contract screen
entry.content:
Dear Community,

We are currently facing an issue where the Posting Parameters tab is not appearing in the RECN Contract screen.

Could you kindly assist us in identifying:

  • Why the Posting Parameters tab is not visible in our RECN screen?
  • What specific configuration settings or screen layout variants need to be activated to enable this tab?
  • Whether any field group assignments or view variants  are required for this functionality?

We would appreciate your guidance on the necessary steps to resolve this and ensure the tab is available for contract postings.

Thanks & regards.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: How to access 'Posting parameters' tab in 'Manage Con...
entry.content:
Hi and thank you for the question!

There are multiple ways to achieve what you are looking for.

The screen sequence can be adjusted for the specific contract type in SSCUI 103849 - Define Contract Types. In this configuration activity, there are several pre-delivered screen sequences which you can review to see which one aligns with your requirements the closest. This screen sequence setting adjusts only the 'Manage Contract' app by contract type maintained.

In addition, posting parameters themselves are accessible directly via the contract condition. You can navigate to the contract condition in question, and select the 'Term' section for the condition. Here, posting terms, frequency terms and more can be maintained directly.

I would also recommend reviewing best practices and test scripts available for the specific scope items via the SAP Help Portal. The documentation explains in detail the functionalities and how to access them, both for the older 'Manage Contract' GUI app, and the new 'Contract Management' Fiori app, which I also recommend checking out as new developments will be focusing on the Fiori Apps.

In the 'Contract Management' App, you can also access the 'Posting Parameters' section and edit the entries directly.

Highlight:

  • The solution provides state of the art solution tailored to cater public sector specific needs from Procure-to-Pay and Source-to-Pay business scenarios.
  • It allows customers to switch individual public sector features catering to their business needs.
  • The solution is integration points with external parties for Contract Authoring as well as Record Management.
  • It has multiple extension points available for customers to make it retrofit into custom developments.

 

Features:

The solution features rich set stretched from Pre-awarding, awarding and Post awarding process in the cycle of Sourcing and Procurement.

The solution is built with close collaboration with major public sectors from US and France to ensure the delivered features will resolve their key challenges and overcome the setback from erstwhile solution. Some notable public sector features are:

  • Smart Numbers
  • De-obligation
  • Pricing Arrangements
  • Incremental Funding with Fund Requests
  • Mixed Contracts
  • Multiple Suppliers
  • Novation

Technical Layout:

The complete solution is compile with suite of fiori applications which can work standalone but best suited when worked in symphony.

The solution leverage latest Restful ABAP Programming framework and Fiori Element 4.0 as technology stack.

The solution delivers multiple business switches as well customizing level switches to ensure customer can activate features which is more relevant.

Behind the scene the solution enriched with full power house of standard procurement and sourcing processes.

Some key applications which is in addition to standard procurement and sourcing application:

  • Manage Fund Request
  • Process Novation
  • Process Deobligation
  • Manage Entity Hierarchies

The product is general availability is active from October 8th, 2025.

More features are in the roadmap for the upcoming feature pack 01.

entry.title: Construction in Progress (CIP) Process using WBS in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
We are implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and need to understand the Construction in Progress (CIP) process using WBS elements instead of internal orders.

**Our Understanding:**
In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:
1. Investment internal orders are not available
2. We should use WBS elements for CIP instead
3. Process flow: Create CIP WBS → WBS Settlement (post to CIP account) → Final Settlement (post to fixed asset master)

**Our Questions:**
1. Which scope items are required to implement this CIP process in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition?
2. Is there a standard process flow or best practice documentation for CIP management using WBS in Cloud Public Edition?

Could you please provide guidance on the standard configuration and scope items needed for this process?

Thank you.

entry.title: Initial System Setup and Ledger Scoping: Project Perspective
entry.content:
Co-authored with @Verena_Stuetz and @SebastianWoedl 

Contents

Introduction
SAP Central Business Configuration activities
  1. Activity: Scope
  2. Activity: Primary Finance Settings
  3. Activity: Organizational Structure
  4. Activity: Configuration
 Ledger scoping and assignment
  Overview
  Important points for decision-making
  Scenario 1: Ledger 0L only
  Scenario 2 & 3: Ledger 0L + 2L/3L
  Scenario 4: Ledger 0L + 2L + 3L
  Scenario 4a: Ledger 0L + 2L + 3L with non-standard group accounting principle
 Summary

Introduction

This blog explores the initial configuration of the global settings in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system. These activities take place immediately after the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system provisioning during the initial set-up.

These activities have to be done in the following systems:

  • Starter system: This system has a set of master data and a set of SAP Best Practice scopes loaded to help you explore its capabilities and conduct the Fit-to-Standard workshop.
  • Your project's Development system: after the Fit-to-Standard workshop the configuration of your project's system can begin.

In this blog, we focus on the concepts that are relevant for the project's Development system.

If you’d like to know more about configuration of Starter System, please check this blog:  From A to Z: Setup a Starter System of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition [2024 Edition]

<back to top>

SAP Central Business Configuration activities

Global settings impact the company’s configuration and master data setup at a tenant level. They have a significant impact on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud implementation project and rollout strategy. After the initial setup, some global settings cannot be changed without system reprovisioning.

According to the SAP Activate methodology, a global settings workshop should be scheduled during the Prepare phase to ensure stakeholders have sufficient time to review all relevant information, align on key considerations, and make well-informed decisions.

During the initial system activation of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, three primary activities must be completed in SAP Central Business Configuration.

Please note that business process configuration (step 4) is not accessible unless the first three steps are completed:

  1. Scope
  2. Primary Finance Settings
  3. Organizational Structure
  4. Configuration

These activities must be performed sequentially. Follow-up activities can only be started after the predecessor has been finalized and its completion has been confirmed by the user.

<back to top>

1. Activity: Scope

In the first phase, the relevant countries and scope items must be selected for system activation. It is possible to choose scope item bundles or individual scope items one by one. Please note that scope items cannot be deactivated after successful activation.

The following screenshot shows the Define Scope section in SAP Central Business Configuration. It highlights the buttons to select the required countries and, as an example, the selection of non-leading 1GA (IFRS).

Figure 1. Central Business Configuration: Define Scope

Attention:

Some scope items can only be added or removed during the initial scoping. A later activation as a scope extension is not possible (example: scope item 1GA). If you do not select the scenario now but need it later, your system will have to be reprovisioned and your project reimplemented.

The respective scope items can be found in the SAP Signavio Process Navigator by filtering for “Initial Activation Only”.

The following screenshot shows the steps to select the Initial Activation Only filter value on the user interface. After first clicking on the filter symbol, choose Additional Information. then select Initial Activation Only.

Figure 2. SAP Signavio Process Navigator: scope items available for initial activation only

If you’d like to know more about scope item activation, please refer to the following SAP Knowledge Base Article (KBA):

3401000 - FAQs about Scope Item Activation / Additional Country Activation in S/4HANA Public Cloud Systems

One of the most important decisions during scope selection is the definition of the standard ledgers, which are represented by scope items:

Scope Item

Ledger

Accounting principle assigned by default on the ledger level

J58

0L (leading)

None (local AP assigned on CoCd level)

1GA

2L

IFRS

2VA

3L

US GAAP

It is mandatory to select at least scope item J58, which comes with the leading ledger 0L. Depending on customer requirements, it is possible to add one or more additional ledgers by selecting additional scope items.

In most cases, SAP recommends activating two ledgers: either (0L and 2L for IFRS) or (0L and 3L for US-GAAP). The decision to add more ledgers should be based on specific business requirements, keeping in mind that this will increase the database volume.

We’ll cover this topic in more detail later.

<back to top>

2. Activity: Primary Finance Settings

In the second phase, two primary finance settings need to be defined:

  • Group Currency
  • Fiscal Year Variant

Once these settings are confirmed, they cannot be changed. The settings are valid on tenant level. Changing these settings requires a full system reprovisioning.

Figure 3. Central Business Configuration: Primary Finance Settings

<back to top>

3. Activity: Organizational Structure

The last step before business process configuration is the definition of the organizational structure. Individual organizational units and their relations are created in the Organizational Structure app in SAP Central Business Configuration.

The following screenshot shows an example of an organizational structure that is being edited and therefore in status In Progress. It also highlights the button to complete this activity.

Figure 4. Central Business Configuration: Organizational Structure

One company code per country has to be marked as default in SAP Central Business Configuration. This is required for the initial preconfigured content deployment. If you’d like to know more about the default company code, please refer to the following KBA:

3580645 - Default Company Code checkbox in SAP Central Business Configuration's Organizational Structure

The following screenshot shows a dialog box for the default company code that is marked as default. The relevant default company code checkmark is selected and greyed out.

Figure 5. Default Company Code

Depending on the selected scope, there is a minimum set of organizational units to be created per country to complete this phase. The Organizational Structure app in SAP Central Business Configuration notifies the user which types of organizational units and which number of units must be created.

The following screenshot shows a dialog box on the Set Up Organizational Structure screen listing an example of 16 mandatory organizational units.

Figure 6. Mandatory Organizational Units

Attention:

After confirming the created units, there is no option to delete or change the ID of the organizational units. Descriptions and addresses can still be edited afterward. Only after this activity is completed, configuration can be started. Before that, the configuration activities are locked.

The following screenshot highlights the Configuration section in SAP Central Business Configuration together with a warning message that the setting up of the organizational structure is still in progress which is why configuration can’t be started yet.

Figure 7. Configuration locked until predecessor activities are completed

<back to top>

4. Activity: Configuration

SAP recommends to start configuration with the Assign Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes configuration activity (ID: 103556). The reason is that it is only possible to change the assignment of accounting principles to ledgers and company codes before the first posting in the system.

Attention:

If a reassignment of accounting principles is required in a system with existing postings, customers can use the Schedule Accounting Data Changes app with the Reset Transaction Data job template. Please note that this functionality can be used in development and test systems but not in the production system. As soon as the first posting is made in the production system, changes to the accounting principles assignment require system reprovisioning.

If you’d like to know more about ledgers and accounting principles, please refer to the following SAP Community blog post:

Accounting Principles, Ledgers, and Parallel Accounting.

To know more about accounting principle assignment and available checks, please refer to the following KBA: 3530183 - Assigning Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Details on Configuration in General Ledger Accounting and Asset Accounting - SAP for Me

<back to top>

Ledger scoping and assignment

Overview

The following screenshot lists the options for ledger combinations that are generally possible in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The options are explained in detail below:

Figure 8. Ledger Scenarios

If you’d like to know more about ledger scoping, please refer to the following SAP Community blog post: Which ledger scenarios are available as of SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2302?

<back to top>

Important points for decision-making

  1. Alternative fiscal year variants (FYV) must be assigned to a non-leading ledger. This should be considered if a rollout to a country with an alternative fiscal year is planned. Example: India – the fiscal year starts on April 1 and ends on March 31, which corresponds to FYV “V3” in SAP. This FYV can only be assigned to a non-leading ledger.
    (see SAP Help Portal: Configuring an Alternative Fiscal Year Variant)
  2. The tax depreciation area in Asset Accounting is deployed only if the local accounting principle is assigned at the company code level.

(see SAP Help Portal: Assign Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes). If you’d like to know more about the setup of ledgers and depreciation areas, please refer to: Setup of Ledgers and Depreciation Areas

<back to top>

Scenario 1: Ledger 0L only

When opting for a single ledger, the local accounting principle is assigned at the company code level (no assignment at the ledger level). IFRS/2L & US-GAAP/3L are not available in the system.

Note:

  1. With a single-ledger setup, there is no option to implement an alternative fiscal year variant.
  2. Tax depreciation area is deployed as local GAAP is assigned on company code level.

 

Ledger

Leading

Corporate Acc. Principle on Ledger Level

DE CoCd

US CoCd

CH CoCd

IN CoCd

0L

X

 

DEAP (K4)

USAP (K4)

CHAP (K4)

INAP (K4)

Table 1.1. Scenario 1: accounting principle and fiscal year assignment

 

Ledger

Leading

Depreciation Area

DE CoCd

IN CoCd

15 - Local Tax

INAP (15)

Table 1.2. Scenario 1: tax depreciation area

<back to top>

Scenario 2 & 3: Ledger 0L + 2L/3L

When opting for a two-ledger setup, the SAP best practice recommendation is to assign the group accounting principle to the leading ledger, which is 0L in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition systems.

 

This means changing pre-delivered content from:

Ledger

Leading

Corporate accounting Principle on Ledger Level

0L

X

IFRS

to:

Ledger

Leading

0L

or similar for ledger 3L and US-GAAP.

 

Note:

  1. Assigning group accounting principle (IFRS or US-GAAP) to 0L allows the implementation of an alternative fiscal year variant for the non-leading ledger (2L or 3L).
  2.  Additional depreciation area for Asset Accounting is only deployed for the non-leading ledger where the local accounting principle is assigned at the company code level.

 

Ledger

Table 2.1. Scenario 2: accounting principle and fiscal year assignment

Table 2.2. Scenario 2: tax depreciation area

The same applies for the scenario 3 (US GAAP/3L instead of IFRS/2L)

<back to top>

Scenario 4: Ledger 0L + 2L + 3L

When selecting all three available ledgers, the SAP best practice recommendation is still to assign the group accounting principle to the leading ledger. It is up to the customer to choose whether this is IFRS or US-GAAP.

Note:

  1. Assigning group accounting principle (IFRS or US GAAP) to 0L allows the implementation of an Alternative Fiscal Year Variant for the non-leading ledger (2L or 3L).
  2. The additional depreciation for Asset Accounting is only deployed for the non-leading ledger where the local accounting principle is assigned at the company code level.

<back to top>

Scenario 4a: Ledger 0L + 2L + 3L with non-standard group accounting principle

Project experience – Requirement for an additional group accounting principle that is not IFRS or US-GAAP:

Consulting is occasionally confronted with the requirement of having two group accounting principles reflected in the system in addition to the local accounting principle (AP). One of the two is an internationally accepted accounting principle like IFRS or US-GAAP, while the second is the local accounting principle of the country where the parent company is located (for example, HGB for Germany).

The business requirement is, for a German company, for example:

  1.                 Group accounting principle 1 (international): IFRS or US GAAP
  2.                Group accounting principle 2 (local for parent company): DEAP (≠IFRS or US-GAAP)

III.              Local GAAP for subsidiaries

First, there is no clear best practice recommendation by SAP to reflect this requirement. Therefore, the following explanations are based on project experience.

Note:

  1. Assigning group accounting principle (IFRS or US-GAAP) to 0L allows the implementation of an alternative fiscal year variant for the non-leading ledger on the company code level (in our example it’s 3L).
  2. The additional depreciation for Asset Accounting is only deployed for the non-leading ledger where the local accounting principle is assigned at the company code level.

When it comes to the requirement of using a local GAAP as a group accounting principle, there is one more technical limitation to be aware of:

  1. an accounting principle can only be assigned twice when one of the assignments is on the leading ledger.

Taking this into consideration, there is one potential way to reflect the requirement while avoiding as many technical restrictions as possible:

 

Ledger

Leading

Corporate Acc. Principle on ledger level

DE CoCd

US CoCd

CH CoCd

IN CoCd

0L

X

DEAP

DEAP

DEAP

DEAP

2L

 

IFRS

3L

 

 

DEAP (K4)

USAP (K4)

CHAP (K4)

INAP (V3)

Table 3.1. Scenario 4a: accounting principle and fiscal year assignment

 

Ledger

Leading

Depreciation Area

DE CoCd

IN CoCd

01 – Book depreciation

34 – Book Depreciation

USAP (34)

CHAP (34)

INAP (34)

Table 3.2. Scenario 2: tax depreciation area

Benefits:

  • Assigning DEAP at the ledger level for the leading ledger 0L allows the assignment of DEAP a second time at the company code level for the non-leading ledger 3L – as the local accounting principle for German company code 1010.
  • Full ledger setup across all company codes.
  • An alternative fiscal year variant can be implemented at the 3L company code level if, for example, the solution will be rolled out to a company code in India.
  • The tax depreciation area is deployed for all company codes on local GAAP.

Constraints:

  • Why is DEAP assigned to 0L and not to 2L? Compared to IFRS, DEAP is not necessarily the “leading” accounting principle from a business perspective; however, it is technically mandatory to have it assigned to the leading ledger (otherwise, it is not possible to use DEAP as the local accounting principle for DE company code 1010).
  • Due to the architecture of universal parallel accounting (UPA) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the importance of the leading ledger has decreased. The main implication of the leading ledger is that it is mandatory for all company codes, while the assignment of a company code to a non-leading ledger can be removed.

Note: Once DEAP is assigned to ledger 0L, the system requests the creation of a new ledger group (using the Define Ledger Group configuration activity (ID: 106930). The ledger ID must consist of two characters, starting with a letter; the namespace 0x-9x is reserved for SAP.

Note: The accounting principle IFRS can be assigned to either ledger 2L or 3L. There are no technical limitations related to that decision; the remaining ledger is then used for the assignment of accounting principles at a company code level.

<back to top>

Summary

  • Global settings are foundational, tenant-level decisions in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition made immediately after system provisioning.
  • Many of these settings are irreversible once confirmed and require a complete system reprovisioning to be changed.
  • Initial setup must be completed in SAP Central Business Configuration through three mandatory, sequential phases: Scope, Primary Finance Settings, and Organizational Structure.
  • The Scope phase involves selecting countries and activating scope items; some crucial items are for "initial activation only" and cannot be added later.
  • The Primary Finance Settings phase permanently defines the group currency and fiscal year variant for the entire tenant.
  • In the Organizational Structure phase, the IDs of created units (for example, company code IDs) become permanent once confirmed.
  • After activation, the first recommended configuration setting is to assign accounting principles to ledgers, as this assignment can only be changed as long as there is no financial posting made in the system.
  • A key consideration is that an alternative fiscal year variant (for example, for India) can only be assigned to a non-leading ledger on company code level.
  • The tax depreciation area for Asset Accounting is only deployed if the local accounting principle is assigned on company code level.
  • For multi-ledger setups, SAP's best practice recommendation is to assign the group accounting principle (IFRS/US-GAAP) to the leading ledger (0L).

<back to top>

entry.title: Re: Goods receipt processing delay in SAP
entry.content:
There can be some delay due to asynchronous process:

  • Update task (v2)
    • Check : SM13 (look for update in progress)
  • tRFC process
    • Check : SM58, SMQ1/2, WE02/05 for status 03, 12 and 41
  • Delay can also be triggered to prevent lock
    • Check: SM12 on order table, SM37 for jobs COCF* or COWB*

entry.title: Re: Designing UI5 Apps as Business Solution for SAP Build Work Zone - Part 2
entry.content:
hi @matthias_schmalz 

I finally managed to make it work!! And the solution is surprisingly simple. As you suggested, it had to do with the security requirement of the app-content:

- name: SupplyControlTower-app-content
  type: com.sap.application.content
  path: .
  requires:
  - name: SupplyControlTower-auth ## this !

Because of that missing requirement, the app-content failed to go through the golden path flow, and the html5 apps had to use the workaround of an added destination!

Sorry for cluttering your comments, and thanks a lot for your patience. I've learned a lot by combing through your tutorials!

Best, 

Theodore.

(I can't overstate how happy I am with this 😁)

entry.title: BAPI_CONTRACT_CHANGE problem with prices
entry.content:
Hello, 
We recently upgraded our SAP system from a very old version (SAP_APPL 604) to SAP_APPL 618 SP 23.

We’re facing an issue where several programs that use BAPI_CONTRACT_CHANGE to modify contracts have stopped working properly when adding new items.

All the new items created with this BAPI are now being created without any price. Before the upgrade, this process worked correctly.

This only happens with new items — if I modify an existing item and add a new condition record through the BAPI, then the price appears correctly.

In the ITEM and ITEMX tables, I’m filling the fields NET_PRICE, PRICE_UNIT, and PO_UNIT.
I’ve also tried filling PO_UNIT_ISO, ORDERPR_UN, and ORDERPR_UN_ISO.
I’ve tested both filling and leaving empty the ITEM_CONDITION and ITEM_COND_VALIDITY tables (and their corresponding _X tables).

But nothing works — the new items still appear without price.

When I click the “Condition Records” button, sometimes it doesn’t show anything or doesn’t go anywhere (in display mode), and other times it shows what looks like an empty condition record.

If I double-click it, a window appears asking for conversion factors, and then I get an error saying I need to specify the unit of measure — but I’m already providing it in the BAPI.

 

Interestingly, if I try to modify this same item later using the BAPI, and I fill the ITEM_CONDITION and ITEM_COND_VALIDITY tables (the same way I did when creating), then the price updates correctly.

I’m not sure if this is some issue related to the unit of measure (sometimes GETDETAIL returns “UNI” and other times “ST”…) or something else.

I’ve checked notes like 1102280 - BAPI_CONTRACT_CHANGE conditions are not created, but it doesn’t apply to our version.

Has anyone faced this issue or has any idea what could be going wrong?

Thanks in advance!

 

EDIT: I've tried creating new items with a different unit, EUR, and in this case is working fine. If there is a problem with the UNI unit, where can I see what is happening? I use tried to use CONVERSION_EXIT_CUNIT_INPUT to transform always de unit to internal format in the BAPI...
